posts.cooked: I am hoping to get a shop in a garage as a mentor to experiment and play around for my own enjoyment and teach what I learn to my teams. I was just curious about what other mentors have learned after doing this and what they would do differently if you could? I really want to build and program my own swerve bot the most and a bot with a turret (never done that before). I have been working on a swerve drive with my team but when limited to shop time it’s gone slowwww. Any advice is welcome!

posts.name: BryanLee
posts.cooked:
This brings up a lot of thoughts, but not sure much advice, lol. One thing I struggle with as a mentor is the fact that it’s often hard to teach something you don’t know so learning it first off site is often better, but at the same time it’s good for the students to go through the process of figuring things out and / or seeing you do it and learning how to figure things out rather than just being given the answers all the time. It’s a tough balance, especially with limited meeting time and short attention spans.

I don’t have a full FRC shop in my garage (though the team has had to build there more then once, luckily not right now) but I do have a fairly decent general shop in my garage. I’ve definitely figured stuff out at home sometimes, then gone back and shared it with the team. Other times I’ve insisted they figure it out, for the learning how to figure things out lesson. I think I change my approach based on the students involved and the problem at hand, and often purposefully only figure out half of the problem myself and make sure they work with me to figure out the other half. I think that eases the process a bit, reduces the pain and boredom a bit in the early stages, but still lets them learn the lessons on how to figure things out rather than waiting for a teacher to give them all the right answers as they are often so used to.

Not sure that’s the type of advice your looking for or if it’s helpful, just what came to mind reading this.

FYI, Im not a teacher, we have no teachers on the team and are not associated with a school, so I don’t know anything official about education.

Several of our mentors have home shops that have been used to make robot parts. The best garage shop our mentor Ulf ( @tribologist ) has includes heating, which is a really nice touch when we need to meet at his house if the school cancels a meeting.

Another tool related note I’d advocate for is nice electrical tools. I feel like its the area where a lot of people will cheap out on when purchasing something for their homes, but Anderson crimpers, nice diagonal cutters/wire cutters, automatic strippers, etc are super critical to ensure you don’t have to repeat shoddy work caused by a bad tool.

My wife and I are in the same boat as you - it would be ideal to have a full set of all FRC components at home so you can learn things yourself which makes mentoring kids a lot easier. Our hope is to get a full control system including rio, just need to find a team willing to sell one!

posts.name: Tim Ehrlich
posts.cooked:
Be realistic with what you want to accomplish.  If it’s just to build an FRC style robot once, that’s different than building one every season, which is also different from then using the space for other tasks on an occasional/common/everyday cadence.  Use this along with the existing skills and equipment of the team(s) you plan to help to plan your space and tool purchases.  It is entirely possible to build a competent and sufficient FRC robot with no more power tools than a handheld drill and sawzall, and decent collection of hand tools.  If you’re building it once, that might be the route to go, but since you’re saying a garage shop, I’m assuming you’re looking for a bit more than that.  The most common items teams use are likely drill presses and band saws, which make a good example to weight that with your “other” level of use to guide what to get.  A big box store drill press will be sufficient for most home type use and still sufficient for building a robot, but if you plan to use the shop of other things or other more advanced types of machining, you might want to forego the drill press entirely, or go with a more advanced unit with a digital read out (DRO) or similar.  Same for the band saw, you can get a lot of mileage out of a benchtop or floor one from a big box store, more than enough to build a robot, but if you’re going to do other work out there as well (maybe some woodworking on the side), you might want to step up to a better unit.  Same goes for all the other possible tools as well.

Consider what power you have available.  We just moved, and the first thing I drew up for the shop building we’ll add eventually was an electricity diagram.  You just can’t usually run a good 120V dust collector and a saw on a 15A circuit (side call out to consider dust collection!  This is your home, you don’t want to be tracking metal swarf all over).  Sometimes you can’t even run a drill press and chop saw on the same 15A circuit.  If you’ll be the only person out there using tools, that’s less of a problem, but if you get or add “set and forget” tools like 3d printers or laser cutters or CNC mills and all, you can quickly run out of power.  That may drive some decisions of what to put in the space.

I’d start off with looking at what tools your team has, and couple that with your wants and budget and start with those.  Building a good technique on a band saw to make accurate cuts, and getting and knowing how to use and using a good fence with it may in itself move your teams forward in their capabilities and quality.  Same with a drill press, a lot of teams never change the belts to do different speeds, but that can make a big difference in both tool life and end result quality, and that’s something to learn by experimenting on different materials, reading spec sheets and machining charts, and then teach.

Add tools as you need them or feel you have sufficient skill with the previous stuff and want to expand your capabilities.  It’s tempting to want to just “outfit” the shop all at once with a laser cutter, CNC mill, 3D printers, all the things, but I personally think that’s only worthwhile if you have a big grant you have to spend, or have to be very selective about what you can fit in your space and have it all planned out for very specific units to maximize what you can fit in the space.  If you have everything, it becomes tempting to use whatever you know best or whatever is the most fun or whatever you want to learn the most rather than actually knowing each tool well and what it can do efficiently and accurately.  You can cut a hole into a plastic part for the bot with a handheld drill, a drill press, a mill, a CNC mill, a lathe possibly, a laser cutter, or print your own piece with a 3d printer.  Only with experience on each will you know which is most appropriate to that specific task.  Then you also wind up with tools that never get used.  If your team doesn’t build designs or do prototyping with laser-cut pieces, it doesn’t make sense to get a laser cutter, at least until you want to introduce that capability to your team.  Once the foundational skills are there, maybe you do find some parts that would probably be more efficient or more accurate to do using a different tool, like a mill or laser cutter, so add that to the skillset and arsenal.  Maybe your team loves coloring the robot, so getting into powder coating parts rather than using spray paint is more worthwhile to grab and maintain student interest and build certain skills (like planning, so they don’t mess up a powder coat with not having made all the holes before coating it or similar).  Consider your goals for your teams, be them student engagement, student enjoyment, design robustness, design flexibility, construction quality, aesthetic quality, and let that guide selecting what to start with, keep it focused to start, and then build from there.

I made a setup in my basement and garage this year, you can see the setup here: Ri3D Redux Shop Prep and Tour | 2023 Charged Up - YouTube

I was prepping for having a group of people show up to throw together a mostly COTS robot though, your setup may be different if less people are going to be there.

link_counts.title: Ri3D Redux Shop Prep and Tour | 2023 Charged Up - YouTube

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
I have a pretty good shop at this point, I only need a vertical bandsaw and a shop vac to finish things up.

Unfortunately I really just like having the tools and seldom use them.

My recommendation is to have everything on wheels to make storage easier. Workbenches, toolboxes, and tools - put some casters on there. Ditto the above sentiments about good wiring equipment. I also have tons of storage boxes and bins as well as a couple of shelves.

My langmuir MR-1 CNC just got delivered. I have a full enclosure for it which will keep chips off the floor. Chips are difficult to clean up out of all the crannies so this was important to me when setting up.

I have hosted robotics teams in my garage in the past, and have not had issues with small groups (up to ~10 people if the software people sit in the kitchen).

posts.name: Sam Knight
posts.cooked:
Since you say “a” garage, are you actually looking for a space or do you have a garage and are looking to get set up from whatever state it’s in now?  There are a bunch of things we had to confront back in 2020 when we lost our lab and had to move into my small home shop.  What tools you already have access to on your own is a factor.  How much you will be doing “robot stuff” vs other stuff in your home shop is another.

There are also several types of work to factor in: metal fabrication, electronics, assembly, and potentially woodwork and that’s just for robots.  These might be beyond whatever other hobbies you already do in your garage.  I spend a lot of time cleaning up in my home shop in between work modes, like if I’m doing woodwork and then I need to be doing electronics or welding, I have to completely clean up one mess before I make a different kind.  Or when you are assembling gear boxes that are covered with grease, you don’t want to be quickly switching modes into making wood dust or metal flakes in the same space without controlling your mess. I put a shop dust collection system on anything that cuts or sands to help mitigate the mess but I still also end up bagging robots that are in the shop while I woodwork etc.

Putting shop tools and benches on rolling bases can help tremendously with optimizing your space if it’s limited, but again, depending on what kind of tooling you will be working with.  For me, I switch modes between “building” hobbies frequently, I do automotive/motorcycle stuff, guitar building, woodwork, bicycle repair, RC and drones, and a bunch of other things (I have way too many hobbies), in my shop I needed to think about what were the things I was going to be doing most often, where to put the tools for each so they were organized, not messing with each other, and how to be able to move stuff to get into whatever work mode I needed to be in without spending half a day getting set up.  Organization and layout is critical if you don’t have a huge space.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked:
Being someone who is currently doing Hobbyist style robotics for a lot of my work, here’s a couple ideas:

Makerspaces I find myself wanting to 3d print or lase cut parts for robots often, as they are cheap ways to prototype quickly. A membership to a makerspace can be cheaper than buying a machine yourself. You’re profile says you’re from San Antonio. There is a place called 10Bitworks that looks promising.

Arduinos Look into using Arduinos early on, they are a pretty cheap “brain” to start with. I go more in-depth in this thread where I talk about creating a mecanum robot.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
asid61:

Unfortunately I really just like having the tools and seldom use them.

My recommendation is to have everything on wheels to make storage easier. Workbenches, toolboxes, and tools - put some casters on there. Ditto the above sentiments about good wiring equipment. I also have tons of storage boxes and bins as well as a couple of shelves.

It appears that you may have T.A.S. **.

Be sure that at least 2 of the casters lock so your equipment doesn’t move while being used.

There are also casters that extend and retract when operated by a foot. When retracted, the legs of the table or equipment stand will contact the floor. Woodworking suppliers such as Rockler, Woodcraft and Lee Valley Tools are good places to find them.

Visit your local bookstore or magazine store and look through the woodworking magazines for ideas for efficient storage and work tables.

Make sure you have adequate access to electrical power for the equipment. Most garages I have seen have only one dual receptacle. Recently, I installed a retractable power cord with a 40 foot reach in the middle of the ceiling and plugged it into the receptacle in the ceiling for the garage door opener. I wish I had done this sooner. While this solution works for me, it may not be adequate when you have a bunch of students visiting, working on a variety of things at the same time.

** Tool Acquisition Syndrome. There is no known cure and there has been no research done to find one…

posts.name: philso

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
Fortunate for me our team’s build space is very accessible. Anyway. Lots of information on the web for designing a home work shop and how to organize tools so they be moved easily into the work space.

If you are going to host people in your work space, you need to think about liability and safety. For example some of my stuff are missing guards that really should have them. Bottom line make sure you have good insurance because there is liability that cannot be signed away.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: My house is 13 years old. Most of my neighbors just park their cars in their garage. A few have one or two boxes from the last large purchases they made in case they need to return them.

posts.name: hpeyerl
posts.cooked:
On the other end of the spectrum, I have 2 shops, each with 100A panels and heat.  Lots of tools and open space.  Unfortunately, one of them is an electronics lab type building packed to the gills with tools, benches, parts, desks and a CNC machine.  The other shop has lots of spinning and arcing power tools but presently houses one project vehicle and frequently houses tractors with hydraulic leaks and occasionally a 30 year old ford plow truck with a leaking rear main seal.   It would take an hour of cleaning just to get enough space to run a robot.

Plus, it’s 90 min drive from the nearest student on the team.

posts.name: Emily Yngstrom
posts.cooked:
Akash_Rastogi:

Another tool related note I’d advocate for is nice electrical tools. I feel like its the area where a lot of people will cheap out on when purchasing something for their homes, but Anderson crimpers, nice diagonal cutters/wire cutters, automatic strippers, etc are super critical to ensure you don’t have to repeat shoddy work caused by a bad tool.

I second this. I’m not particularly interested in the electrical side of things but having a parent who is an electrical engineer I’ve ended up with some higher quality tools over the years. One of the best tools I ever bought myself was a proper pair of knipex combination wire cutters and strippers. Even for someone who does minimal electrical work having nicer tools makes it so much easier. Good electrical tools can also make it a lot easier to justify buying older equipment whos electrics are not good and need some repair. Great way to get some money off of larger tools.

Might get a little bit of backlash for this one but I’d honestly suggest a proper used Bridgeport(Or any kneemill) with a dro and maybe a smaller lathe. Doesn’t have to be a full 50in table version or anything but having a mill is so darn useful I’ve found and opens up so many possibilities. I don’t personally have one at home but I have access to several at work (I run the machine shop at an electrical engineering firm) and this has allowed me to quickly prototype ideas and I honestly don’t know what i’d do without it. Also outside of robot stuff the amount of crap around your home that you can fix with a mill and a lathe is substantial so over the long run it could very well pay for itself kind of like the lathe I have did.
